narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much in this course! Dr. White taught the foundational epidemiological principles and seeing how epidemiology is used in public health.
Everything about epidemiological statistics and studies was super helpful, especially for anyone who wants to go into the medical or public health field

I learned how to read scientific studies and evaluate popular media's representation of studies; how to more accurately discuss epidemiological issues/statistics + better understand scientific discussion of the same. Learned to think creatively about public health responses
Epidemiology! great intro to the concepts
Understanding the tools and metrics used to track the spread of a disease, to determine the potential cause of a disease, and to examine the impacts of such diseases.

This course provides a wonderful introduction to epidemiology, including statistical analysis, research design, and experimental design. The content in the lectures is reinforced through group case studies, which occur once a week during class time. At first, these were a bit intimidating because they are somewhat long. However, they are very doable, especially in a group! They consist of analyzing/evaluating scientific papers, applying lecture concepts, and learning the program SPSS (which is also covered in lectures). By the end, I was surprised by how well I could work in a group, even on Zoom!

We learned a lot about how to analyze and understand information through the lens of public health and epidemiology. I noticed this information changing how I view and perceive the COVID-19 pandemic in real-time. It gave insight as well into how to read and assess scientific papers/studies and measure their validity or extract general understandings that will be helpful going forward. I learned so much about different types of studies and how to set one up in the way most conducive to testing the intended question and how to properly write and prepare surveys. I learned a lot about how as a future doctor, understanding public health can be helpful in properly explaining information, such as test sensitivity and specificity, to patients. Additionally, we were introduced to SPSS which is data analysis software and will be very helpful in the future regardless of if one is further pursuing public health. We learned as well how helpful taking care of ourselves in small ways can really help us be healthier and happier which was indescribably timely during COVID-19. The global health case competition group assignment also was a great opportunity to apply our learnings on a global scale which was especially rewarding for those really interested in global health. This is just a brief overview of so many active skills that we learned in this class!
Learn the basics of epidemiology, research design, how to use SPSS, and public health problem solving
Epidemiology terms and basics, SPSS
This class provides a very useful background in public health and SPSS.

I gained an in-depth understanding of public health and epidemiology, including common methods and measurements. In addition, I developed my ability to critically evaluate research and how it is presented to the public.

I understood the makeup of global affairs from a health perspective, and gleaned how diseases in a global context are studied and how treatment is implemented on primary, secondary, and tertiary levels.

This course taught me much about epidemiology and about how it is carried about in the real world. Through the cases and class discussions, I learned about many of the practical applications of epidemiology and public health.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No weaknessses! You can tell Prof. White enjoys teaching the class. I thought the way assignments were weighted and divided was fair and I enjoyed working on the variety of weekly cases with other people. I also loved her idea of the mental health pset  it actually made a huge difference in how I carried and maintained my health throughout the semester, and I thank her for that!

This is a great courseDr. White is incredible, and one of those professors who genuinely cares about her students and her students' learning. She's the most important strength of this course. It's also generally thoughtfully designedit touches on public health/epidemiology from lots of different angles, and there are a lot of different opportunities for learning (ie, time spent on SPSS, time spent working in groups on cases, reading, low-pressure quizzes, the health case competition group project, the daily health goals assignment). We engaged a lot on current issues (obviously...) and I also really appreciated that. 

Honestly, I think that one of the only ways this course could be improved were if it could meet in person, which will hopefully happen next year. Dr. White showed us a lecture or two of her teaching in person, and I really hope future students get to experience that energy.

strengths- professor amazing, so sweet, loved her, so smart
weakness- not really any, but i think an exam or something may have helped me retain the info a little better, because there was no active recall

One of the greatest strengths of this class is the group case studies. They help reinforce the knowledge gained from lectures and also encourage collaboration, which is important in public health (or any field, actually)! They can be a bit long and sometimes challenging, but the TAs and the professor are always there to offer help at any moment. However, if you do not work well with groups, this may be a little stressful (but also helpful to sharpen your group skills!). 
Also, Professor White made self care an assignment! This helped me actually put effort into my well-being throughout the semester, which was really important especially due to Zoom fatigue and all the stress from the pandemic. 
One potential downside is learning SPSS. It's a little challenging, but Professor White walks you through everything that you have to know, so it's definitely doable (I had no coding experience going into the class and I was fine).

Strengths: 
Professor White and the TAs- They make the energy of the class so comfortable and fun which makes engaging in the class feel so natural and easy.  
Real-world applications- everything in this class has a real-world application that immediately made my understanding of public health much more sophisticated and gives a general context to all of my future learning in public health and epidemiology. 
20% of our grade was dependent on us committing to wellness practices and taking care of ourselves... amazing
Statistics!!! We learn some statistics which is super helpful to those who haven't taken statistics or want to soon. However, you absolutely do not need any stats background to do really well. 
The days we worked on cases were really fun (even on zoom) and you learn a lot from your peers and make friends! 

Weaknesses: 
A lot of information in the lectures! I came up with a system to take notes and return to lectures again later to understand them more deeply later OR I focused on understanding more information in lecture and returned to take brief notes later as it was a little difficult to do both because lectures moved quickly. Makes sense though because we had only one lecture a week with case studies on Wednesdays.
The course was perfect me, although it's important to note that I had a background in stats and public health

I really like the format of the course which was a mixture of lectures and group work. Doing hands-on problems was the best way to learn the material. The only thing that could be improved is instructions for some of the questions. I felt that sometimes instructions for projects/problem sets were a bit vague. But that is also consistent with the nature of public health where there are many correct answers.

Strengths- case days were very engaging and hands-on, professor and TAs were always available to answer questions
Weaknesses- lecture days were often dry; attendance not mandatory, so many students would not show up

The course was organized in a way that allowed the material to build on itself, with the perfect amount of practice! I enjoyed Dr, White's ability to make the topics in the class enjoyable and relate them back to real-life examples.
I liked that the course was focused more on discussions and applications of the material that we learn, instead of just the lectures. I also appreciated the focus on mental health in the course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I don't think anything needs to be improved. I also loved her idea of the mental health pset; it actually made a huge difference in how I carried and maintained my health throughout the semester, and I thank her for that! I also think Prof. White is the only professor this semester who truly cared about the mental health of her students and went beyond the "make sure to take breaks." Her teaching style and class format is honestly the reason why this has been my favorite class this semester.

Most of my professors this year expressed outward empathy about how difficult/isolating this semester was, but Dr. White was pretty much the only one who appeared to actually alter her course's expectations or design in a positive way. I appreciated how flexible she wasdoing weekly quizzes instead of a midterm (probably better to stay on track anyway), doing an open note final (that I actually kind of enjoyed taking). It mattered that she actually asked us how we were doing (and was prepared to hear more than "OK." Incidentally, I feel like I learned more in this course than in others with higher workloads/where professors were less accommodating. (This is totally unsurprising to me but may be to some in the Yale admin, who, beyond my HOC, seem driven to making this semester even more miserable than it needed to bewhy did we need to register and apply for courses, which is a notoriously complicated and time-consuming process, DURING finals??) Anyway, Dr. White clearly thought hard about transitioning to an online format, and her work and empathy should be applauded.

success- prerecorded and online lectures
failure- n/a
Recorded lectures were very helpful for the reviewing of materials. Virtual case studies in breakout rooms were very successful.

The grade breakdown was extremely helpful. The final was worth 20%, so we did not have to worry excessively about that one assignment. Additionally, there were quizzes (rather than midterms) for every lecture that helped me keep up with the material at a more feasible pace. Additionally, two of the psets were part of a self-care assignment, which was awesome!

Having 20% of our grade be dependent on participating in mental health practices was so helpful in maintaining energy and engagement in the course and the semester as a whole during such a difficult time for many. The group case studies on Wednesdays were really helpful in maintaining the collaborative energy that is typically there during a normal semester. The weekly quizzes, although I am not sure these were new to this semester, were helpful in keeping me engaged with the material consistently while learning virtually, but they were not very stressful!
The course was well structures, the professor was incredibly supportive and understanding, and the TAs were also great
The course format worked well over zoom. I feel like for a semi-seminar class like this, the format was optimized.
Strengths- good use of breakout rooms for case studies and group work
The asynchronous lectures were great and allowed me to review the material multiple times. The cases studies were also an excellent way to get hands on experience with data.
All was top notch! I loved the course
The discussion focused live sessions allowed for virtual engagement. This encouraged participation amongst students and was a great way to engage with other students in the class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES!! Take it! Even if you have a slight interest in public health, I'd still take it. Prof. White is honestly one of the best professors at Yale.
Yes! Absolutely
Yes! Professor White is incredible.

Absolutely. Dr. White is incredible. I came into this course with very dormant intro stats knowledge and basically no experience with public health (other than a first-year seminar which covered fairly different topics), and I felt completely prepared to succeed. I feel like I have a very good baseline understanding of epidemiology now, and especially that I'm better prepared to understanding discussions of public health interventions/vaccine discussions/etc/etc related to COVID. The workload is extremely manageableyou need to be prepared to really dig into and understand the material, but I felt that it required more quality time from me than quantity of time. This class was a light spot in what was otherwise a pretty terrible semester.
Yes. Absolutely. Incredible teacher, reasonable grading, learned a lot and very interesting

Yes, definitely. Professor White is very nice and patient with questions, and uses great examples to explain the course's concepts. The case studies added a very hands-on element to the application of the concepts, and guidance was abundant in every piece of work. I never felt lost in the course, and learned many concepts that I can apply confidently to real life.
YES! If you are interested in public health and the science behind it, this is a great introductory course.

YES! You will learn so much about public health and epidemiology that will be useful no matter what your major is/what you study. I especially recommend it to those who are pursuing studies in these specific areas but also to anyone who is interested in health as a general topic. During the COVID-19 era, everything in this class was extra interesting and insightful to understanding how public health has been shaped by and also shapes the pandemic.
yes, only if it's offered by Professor Marney White, she makes the course
Yes! Professor White is such an amazing person + lecturer and the course content is very interesting. If you have an interest in public health, the course is worth taking.

I would recommend this course to any student wishing to solidify an interest in the public health field.  Although, this course seems more tailored to the research aspect of the field, the course material still seems useful.

Yes11 If a student is already interested in Public Health and epidemiology or just has an inkling,  this is a GREAT beginning course. I provide enough depth to get a taste of the field, yet it is still able to show the versatility and diversity of people in the profession.

Definitely! If a student is passionate about health in global contexts and would like to understand just how the health system targets diseases, this is it. The professor is wonderful and extremely understanding.
Yes
I would recommend this to any student who would like to learn about public health and epidemiological practices in an environment where the professor cares about her students and how much they learn.
Yes Marney White is an amazing professor
